100daysofgoodux100daysproject

Day 5: Marshalls Dressing Room

What it is: In the dressing room at Marshalls (A discount clothing retailer) the hooks on the walls for hangers are labeled with small signs reading “Definitely,” “Possibly,” and “Tomorrow”

Why it’s good: Trying on clothes is not an incredibly fun experience, so anything that makes me more comfortable is welcome. In one corner, “Definitely” and “Possibly” are right next to each other, allowing for quick comparisons. “Tomorrow,” while not being incredibly well labelled, is across the room, giving some separation. With a few simple signs (and some great natural feeling light), Marshalls subtlety directs the entire experience.

day 4 pocket clipboard what is is pocket is an

100daysofgoodux100daysproject

Day 4: Pocket Clipboard

What is is: Pocket is an app that helps you keep track of things you want to read. On iOS, when you open the app while you have a URL on your clipboard, Pocket asks if you would like to save it.

Why it’s good: One of the more frustrating behaviors on iOS is the limited way that apps are allowed to talk to each other. If your data cannot be pushed through the native share functionality, there’s no way to get information between apps, right?

What’s so lovely about this small, unobtrusive interaction is that Pocket realizes that you cannot always share a url that you want to save, sometimes it comes up in a weird place that doesn’t allow you that flexibility. This little interaction doesn’t get in your way, but it does realize that if you have a URL that you’ve copied, you probably want to do something with it.

day 3 kickstarter newsletter what it is

100daysofgoodux100daysproject

Day 3: Kickstarter Newsletter

What it is: Kickstarter newsletter sign up in the footer of their site. Clicking the scissors three times causes the footer to fall off and the sign up form to appear in its place.

Why it’s good: I have a special dislike for mailing list signups, largely because so many sites seem to bludgeon me over the head with them. Kickstarter’s newsletter signup sets a completely different tone for what they’re accomplishing, you aren’t just opting to recieve emails, you’re joining the club.

This is a true example of delightful design; The designers didn’t just craft a goofy animation, it’s a genuinely suprising effect. It is a perfect support to Kickstarter’s playful, small company image, quite a feat considering their size and revenue.

day 2 beam telepresence what it is a mobile

100daysofgoodux100daysproject

Day 2: Beam Telepresence

What it is: A mobile robot, about 5'7" tall and remotely controlled. The user has an interface that allows them to drive the robot around and it has 2 way voice and visual communication.

Why it’s good: The woman pictured here is Kavita Krishnaswami - a PHD student in Computer Science at UMBC. Kavita’s physical disabilities render her bedridden, so she attends conferences and gives talks with the Beam Telepresence.

I met her this past Wednesday at her presentation on robotics and disability. She came up to me, we introduced ourselves, spoke for a bit, and then broke off the conversation naturally. I had a thrill when I realized the agency that this machine provided her that cannot be matched by a Skype call, or even a wheelchair.

The makers of this product have put a lot of time into making it feel natural and considering who will use it and how. The height of the screen and camera are at about average eye level. The robot is quick, but not so much so that it’s unstable or disconcerting. There are small details too, like lights illuminating the support pillars, making it so the robot isn’t just a floating screen in dark environments.

At one point in her presentation, Kavita described the first time using a beam, saying “It was the first time I had ever stood.” This product is clearly informed by a deep understanding of the motivations and needs of its users, and that is instantly apparent when you see it in use.

day 1 tumblr dashboard

100daysofgoodux100daysproject

Day 1: Tumblr Dashboard

What it is: This is the second step after I create my account, after skipping the “follow these blogs” step. Suggested content appears all around, but this is clearly the center of the interface.

Why it’s good: The animation is subtle, but friendly. It draws me to the center of the screen, uses casual and accessible language, and indicates interactivity. The dashed lines act as a wireframe to indicate how content will come in if I follow blogs, avatar and posts. There are also more subtle things going on, like introducing you to the unique icon that Tumblr uses for “Link.”

This ends up for a great launch point to start my blog. It doesn’t feel like a huge deal, it feels natural, easy, and directed.
